content.description: <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus Z n solid react to produce C u solid plus Z n with a positive 2 charge aqueous. E naught equals positive 1.10 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Zn(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>) </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The galvanic cell illustrated above generates a potential of <math alttext="positive 1.10 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. For the construction of a second galvanic cell (not shown), only one modification was made: the <math alttext="C u" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode has double the mass of the <math alttext="C u" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode in the first cell. Which of the following correctly compares the initial <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the second cell to that of first cell at <math alttext="298 kelvins" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why?

choices.label: The initial <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the second cell is twice that of the first cell, because a larger amount of <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> can be oxidized to <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The initial <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the second cell is twice that of the first cell, because more <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions can be deposited on the solid <math alttext="C u" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode.

The initial <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the second cell is half that of the first cell, because the greater amount <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the half-cell inhibits the formation of more <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The initial <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the second cell is the same as for the first cell, because the overall chemical reaction that occurs in the cell does not change.

content.answer: The initial <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the second cell is the same as for the first cell, because the overall chemical reaction that occurs in the cell does not change.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
